steps.title: Visit your doctor.
steps.content: Visit your doctor. If you believe you are experiencing ocular rosacea, it is best to consult your doctor. [3] X Expert Source Lydia Shedlofsky, DO Dermatologist Expert Interview. 11 November 2020. Your eye doctor or general practitioner is the best person to diagnose and treat ocular rosacea. Severe or untreated problems can lead to scarring on the eyelid or corneal abrasions, both of which can impact your vision. That is why it is best to talk to a doctor when you first notice early symptoms. Common symptoms include: [4] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Opthamologists Professional medical organization focused on advocating for public health and supporting sight-related research Go to source Dry eyes Eye itchiness Feeling something gritty in your eyes Burning in the eyes Sensitivity to light Blurred vision Eye redness Swollen eyelids Watery eyes

steps.title: Use prescription oral antibiotics.
steps.content: Use prescription oral antibiotics. Most of the time your doctor will prescribe antibiotics to help clear up and treat ocular rosacea. [5] X Expert Source Lydia Shedlofsky, DO Dermatologist Expert Interview. 11 November 2020. You may be asked to take oral antibiotics for up to 1 month. Common medications include tetracycline, doxycycline, erythromycin, minocycline. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Your doctor may choose a particular drug based on your medical history and specific symptoms.

steps.title: Clean your eyelids twice a day.
steps.content: Clean your eyelids twice a day. Dip a cotton swab in warm water and move it across your eyelid. Use it to remove any debris and/or oil from your eyelid. Repeat on the other eye, and complete this practice twice a day. [7] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source Your doctor may advise you to use very diluted baby shampoo to cleanse your eyelids instead of plain water. [8] X Expert Source Lydia Shedlofsky, DO Dermatologist Expert Interview. 11 November 2020.

steps.title: Apply a warm compress to dilate blocked glands.
steps.content: Apply a warm compress to dilate blocked glands. Soak a clean washcloth in hot water. Wring out the washcloth, lie back, and place the washcloth over your closed eyes. Leave it there for 5-10 minutes. This should both loosen your blocked glands and help to soften any remaining debris. [9] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source You may want to clean your eyelids again if the warm compress loosens any excess oil or debris.

steps.title: Avoid makeup.
steps.content: Avoid makeup. In the midst of a flare up, it is best to avoid make up completely. Also avoid using facial care products that contain fragrances or other skin irritants. In most cases, you can resume using non-comedogenic makeup after your flare up is over. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Opt for glasses over contact lenses.
steps.content: Opt for glasses over contact lenses. While your eyes are irritated, it is best not to use contact lenses. Wear glasses instead, and give your eyes the opportunity to heal. In most cases, you will be able to resume the use of contact lenses after your flare up has passed. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Use isotonic eyedrops.
steps.content: Use isotonic eyedrops. [12] X Expert Source Lydia Shedlofsky, DO Dermatologist Expert Interview. 11 November 2020. If your ocular rosacea results in dry eyes, you can control this symptom with artificial tears. Look for preservative-free artificial tears. Add these drops to your eyes as needed, up to 5 times per day. [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Recognize that this condition is chronic.
steps.content: Recognize that this condition is chronic. Although ocular rosacea can usually be controlled with medication and other remedies, these actions don't actually cure the condition. Ocular rosacea is considered chronic and recurring, although many people experience periods of remission. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Continue to practice eyelid hygiene.
steps.content: Continue to practice eyelid hygiene. You can help to prevent flare ups of ocular rosacea by continuing to wash your eyelids 1-2 times per day, even when you are not exhibiting rosacea symptoms. Try making this a regular part of your grooming routine. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid hot, spicy foods.
steps.content: Avoid hot, spicy foods. Ocular rosacea can be brought on by different triggers for different people. For some people, eating hot, spicy foods can signal a flare up. If this is true for you, avoid eating these foods. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Limit alcoholic beverages.
steps.content: Limit alcoholic beverages. Another potential rosacea trigger is alcohol. If you find that you are prone to rosacea flare-ups after consuming alcohol, you should probably avoid it. Try limiting yourself to 1-2 drinks per week. [17] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Use only non-comedogenic and fragrance-free products.
steps.content: Use only non-comedogenic and fragrance-free products. When you are not experiencing a flare up, it is probably safe to use makeup and other cosmetics. However, it is important to make sure that the products you use are fragrance-free and non-comedogenic. [18] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Look for labels on cosmetic products that read fragrance-free and non-comedogenic. Shop at health foods store and specialty cosmetic stores to find special products.

steps.title: Limit your sun exposure.
steps.content: Limit your sun exposure. Sun exposure is another common rosacea trigger. Use a sunhat, wear sunglasses, and apply sunscreen any time you'll be out in the sun. Limit the amount of time you spend in direct sunlight. Never use tanning beds. [19] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Consume flaxseed oil regularly.
steps.content: Consume flaxseed oil regularly. Some research indicates that consuming flaxseed oil, which is rich in omega-3 fatty acids, can help reduce flare-ups of rosacea. Look for flaxseed oil, flaxseed supplement capsules, or whole flaxseed at grocery stores and health food stores. [20] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Try to consume about 2–3 teaspoons (9.9–14.8 ml) of flaxseed oil or 0.125 cups (30 ml) of ground flaxseed each day.
